chunks.text: All right, everyone.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Good afternoon.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's get started.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So today's lecture will be on testing, debugging, and then

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: exceptions and assertions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So before we begin, let's start with an analogy

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to sort of come back to real life for a second.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I've made soup before.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Perhaps you've made soup before.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's say you're making soup in this big pot here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it turns out that bugs keep falling into your soup

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from the ceiling.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, quick just question to the audience.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What do you do if you encounter this issue?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, hands up one at a time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Anyone have any idea?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Yeah?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Eat it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You want to eat it anyway?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, we're going for an analogy

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: here with computer programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I don't know what you do if you have a buggy program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I guess you just release it to the customer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and they'd complain.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But OK, what else?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Yeah?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Cover the soup.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's a good suggestion.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Yeah.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you can cover the soup.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So put a lid on it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Sometimes you'd have to take the lid off

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to check to make sure it's done, to taste it, add things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So bugs might fall in in between there.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But covering the soup is a good idea.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What else?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Yeah?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Debug it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Debug it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I wish I had something for that answer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, that's a good answer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Yeah?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Take all the food out of your house

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and just throw it in the water.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So take all the food out of your house

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: so there's nothing for the bugs to eat.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's sort of the equivalent of cleaning,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: like doing a mass cleaning of your entire house.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's a good one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's sort of eliminating the source of the bugs, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What else?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Yeah, John?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Decide it's high protein and declare it a feature.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Decide it's high protein and declare it a feature.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's probably what a lot of people would do, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, cool.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I wish computer debugging was as fun as taking bugs out

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of your soup.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what did we decide?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, we could check the soup for bugs, keep the lid closed.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That was a good suggestion.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And cleaning your kitchen, which someone suggested

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the equivalent of cleaning their kitchen

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: was to just throw out all the food.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I would take a mop and clean the floor.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But yeah, that works too.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we can draw some parallels for this analogy

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with computer programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So checking the soup is really equivalent to testing, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You have a soup.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You think it has bugs in it, test it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Make sure there's no bugs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Continue on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Keeping the lid closed, it's sort

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of this idea of defensive programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So make sure that bugs don't fall in in the first place.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Sometimes you have to open the lid

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to make sure that the soup tastes good or whatever.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's equivalent to defensive programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So try not to have bugs in the first place,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but they might show up anyway.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Cleaning the kitchen is a limiting source

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of the bugs in the first place.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is actually really hard to do in programming,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but you can still try to do it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, so let's talk a little bit about programming so far

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you expect really that you write a program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You maybe do a little debugging, and you run the program,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and it's perfect, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You just nailed it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But in reality, you write this really complex piece of code,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and you go to run it, and it crashes, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's happened to me many times.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's happened to you many times.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's the reality.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, so today's lecture will sort of go over

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: some tips and tricks on debugging

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and how you can help make your life easier when you're

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: writing programs so you don't end up like this little girl

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: here, disappointed beyond belief.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, so at the heart of it all

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is really starting with a defensive programming attitude.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this comes back to the idea of decomposition

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and abstraction that we talked about when we did

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the lecture on functions, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So try to start out with to modularize your code, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you write your code in different blocks,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: documenting each different block,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you're more likely to understand what's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: happening in your code later on, and you'll

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: be able to test it and debug it a lot easier.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Speaking of testing and debugging,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: once you've written a program that's modular,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you still have to test it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the process of testing is really just coming up

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with inputs, figuring out what outputs you expect,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and then running your program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Does the output that the program give

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: match what you expected?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If it does, great, you're done.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But if it doesn't, you have to go to this debugging step.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this debugging step is the hardest part,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and it's really just figuring out why the program crashed

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or why the program didn't give you the answer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you expected it to give.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, so as I mentioned, the most important thing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is to do defensive programming, and to that end,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you want to set yourself up for easy testing and debugging,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which really comes down to making sure that the code you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: write is modular.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So write as many functions as you can.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Document what the functions do.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Document their constraints.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it'll make your life a little bit easier later on

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: when you have to debug it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: When do you want to start testing?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, first you have to make sure your program runs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So eliminate syntax errors and static semantic errors,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which, by the way, Python can easily catch for you.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Once you've ensured that a piece of code runs,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then you want to come up with some test cases.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is pairs of input and output

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for what you expect the program to do.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Once you have your test cases and a piece of code that runs,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can start doing tests.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So there's three general classes of tests that you can do.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The first is called unit testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if you've written functions, unit testing just

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: makes sure that, for example, each function

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: runs according to the specifications.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you do this multiple times.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: As you're testing each function, you might find a bug.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: At that point, you do regression testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Come up with a test case that found that bug.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And run all of the different pieces of your code

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: again to make sure that when you fix the bug,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you don't reintroduce new bugs into pieces of the code

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that had already run.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you do this a bunch of times.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You do a little bit of unit testing,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a little bit of regression testing, and keep doing that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: At some point, you're ready to do integration testing, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: means test your program as a whole.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Does the overall program work?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is the part where you take all of the individual

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: pieces, put them together, and integration testing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: tests to make sure that the interactions

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: between all of the different pieces works as expected.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If it does, great, you're done.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But if it doesn't, then you'll have

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to go back to unit testing and regression testing and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's really a cycle of testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what are some testing approaches?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The first, and this is probably most common with programs

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that involve numbers, is figuring out

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: some natural boundaries for the program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for example, if I have a function is bigger,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and it compares if x is bigger than y,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then some natural boundary given the specification

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is if x is less than y, x is greater than y, x is equal to y,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: maybe throw in less than or equal to, or greater or equal

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to, and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's just sort of an intuition about the problem.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's possible you have some problems for which there

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are no natural partitions, in which case

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you might do some random testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then the more random testing you do,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the greater the likelihood that your program is correct.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But there's actually two more rigorous ways to do testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And one is black box testing, and the other one

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is glass box testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In black box testing, you're assuming

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you have the specifications to a function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's the doc string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All you're looking at is the doc string

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and coming up with some test cases based on that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In glass box testing, you have the code itself,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and you're trying to come up with some test cases that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: hit upon all of the possible paths through the code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's look at an example for black box testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm finding the square root of x to some close enough value

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: given by this epsilon.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the idea here, notice I don't actually

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: give you how this function is implemented.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The idea is that you're just figuring out test cases

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: based on this specification.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the great thing about black box testing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is that whoever implements this function

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can implement it in whatever way they wish.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They can use approximation method.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They can use bisection method.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It doesn't matter.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The test cases that you come up with for this function

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are going to be exactly the same,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: no matter what the implementation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for this particular function, here's a sample set.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We check the boundary.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We check perfect squares.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We can check some number that's less than 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We can check maybe your rationals.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you do extreme tests.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when either epsilon is really large

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or epsilon is really small or x is really large

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or x is really small and all the possible combinations of those.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the important thing about black box testing is that you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are creating the test cases based on the specifications

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: only.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Glass box testing, you're using the code itself

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to guide your test cases.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you have a piece of code and you come up with a test case

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that goes through every single possible combination

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of every single possible path through the code,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then that test set is called path complete.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The problem with this is when you encounter loops,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Every single possible path through a loop

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is maybe the code not going through the loop at all,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going through once, going through twice,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going through three times, four times, five times, and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Which could be a very, very big test set.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So instead, there are actually some guidelines

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for when you're dealing with loops and things like that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for branches, when you're doing glass box testing,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it's important you should just exercise all

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of the parts of the conditional.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So make sure you have a test case that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: goes through each part of the conditional.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For for loops, make sure you have a test case where

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the loop is not entered at all, whether the loop is entered

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: one time and when the loop is entered just some number

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: more than once.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For while loops, similar to for loops,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: except that make sure you have test cases that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: cover all of the possible ways to break out of the while loop.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if the while loop condition becomes false,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or if maybe there's a break inside the while loop,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in this example, we have the absolute value of x.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is a specification, and this is the implementation

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that someone decided to do for this function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So a path complete test set means

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you want to have a test that goes through each one

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of these branches.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if x is less than minus 1, well, minus 2

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is less than minus 1, so that's good.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And otherwise, which means pick a number greater than minus 1,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: so 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So 2 and minus 2 are path complete,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: yields a path complete test suite.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But notice that while we've hit upon every possible path

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: through this code, we've actually

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: missed a test case, minus 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this code incorrectly classifies minus 1

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as returning minus 1, which is wrong.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for glass box testing, in addition to making sure

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you're going through all the possible paths through the code,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you also want to make sure you hit upon any boundary

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: condition.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in this case, for branches, minus 1 is a boundary condition.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you've created a test suite.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You've tested your program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Chances are you found a bug.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What do you do now?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Quick detour into a little bit of history,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the history of debugging.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So 1947, this computer was built.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it was a computer that was very impressive for its day.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It could do things like addition in 0.1 seconds,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: things like multiplication in 0.7 seconds,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and take the log of something in five seconds.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So faster than a human, possibly,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but pretty slow for today's standards.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And a group of engineers were working

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: on running a program that was supposed

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to find the trigonometric function,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and among them being one of the first female scientists,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Grace Hopper.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And they found that their program was not working correctly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So they went through all of the panels and all

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of the relays in the computer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And they isolated a program in panel F, relay 70,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: where they found this moth just sitting in there.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I think it was dead, probably electrocuted.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But it was a moth that was impeding the calculation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I don't know if you can read this, but this part right

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: here, they made a note in their logbook

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that says, first actual case of bug being found, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I think is really cute.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So they were literally doing debugging in this computer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you won't be doing that sort of debugging.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You'll be doing a virtual kind of debugging

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in your programs, which again is not that fun.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But you still have to do it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So debugging, as you might have noticed so far

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in your problem sets, has a bit of a steep learning curve.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And obviously, your goal is to have a bug-free program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in order to achieve that, you have to do the debugging.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There are some tools which some of you have been using.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There are some tools built into Anaconda,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or whatever ID you've been using to do debugging.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I know some of you have been using the Python

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Tutor, which is awesome.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The print statement can also be a good debugging tool.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But above everything else, it's really

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: important to just be systematic as you're

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: trying to debug your program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I want to talk a little bit about print statements

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and how you can use them to debug.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because I think Python Tutor, if you don't have the internet,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you might not be able to use it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you don't know how to use the debugger,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you don't need to learn.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But print statements, you'll always have them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can always put them in your program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And they're really good ways to test hypotheses.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So good places to put print statements

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are inside functions, inside loops, for example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What are the loop parameters?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What are the loop values?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What functions return what values?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you can make sure that the correct values

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are being passed between parts of your code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I will mention that you can use the bisection method

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: when you're debugging, which is interesting.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if you take a print statement,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: find approximately the halfway point in your code,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: print out some relevant values.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Print out some values at that point in your code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If everything is as you expect it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to be at that point in your code, then you're good.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That means the code so far is bug free.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: However, that means that the code beyond it has a bug.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So since you've put a print statement halfway in your code

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and you think that gave good results,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then put a print statement 3 quarters of the way in the code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And see if the values are as you expect at that point.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if they are, great.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Then put a print statement further down.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in this way, you could use the bisection method

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to pinpoint a line or a set of lines

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or maybe a function that's giving you the bad results.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the general debugging steps is to study the program code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Don't ask what is wrong, because that's actually

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: part of the testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Your test cases would have figured out what's wrong.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The debugging process is figuring out

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how the result took place.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And since programming and debugging is a science,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can use a scientific method as well.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So look at all the data.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's your test cases.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Figure out a hypothesis.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Maybe say, oh, maybe I'm indexing from 1 instead of 0

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in lists, for example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Come up with an experiment that you can repeat.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then pick a simple test case that you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can test your hypothesis with.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So as you're debugging, you will encounter error messages.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these error messages are actually

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: pretty easy to figure out.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And they're really easy to fix in your code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for example, accessing things beyond the limits of a list

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: give you index errors.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Trying to convert, in this case, a list to an integer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: gives you type errors.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Accessing variables that you haven't created before

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: gives you name errors, and so on and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And syntax errors are for things like if you forget a parentheses

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or forget a colon or something like that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So error messages are really easy to spot.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The Python interpreter spits these out for you.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you can pinpoint the exact line.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Logic errors are actually the hard part.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And logic errors are the ones that you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: will be spending the most time on,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for which I would recommend always trying to take a break,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: take a nap, go eat, something.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Sometimes you'd have to start all over.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So throw out the code you have and just

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: sit down with a piece of paper, try

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to figure out how you want to solve the problem.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if you look up the term rubber ducky,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a lot of heads went up on that one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Rubber ducky debugging, that is an actual term in Wikipedia.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's when a programmer explains

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: their code to a rubber ducky.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's me on the left explaining code to my rubber ducky.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You should always go buy one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or code to anyone else, preferably someone

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: who doesn't really understand anything,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because that will force you to explain everything really,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: really closely.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And as you're doing that, you'll figure out your problem.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I figured out my problem in both of these cases.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So just go back to the basics.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Quick summary of do's and don'ts of debugging and testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So don't write the entire program,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: test the entire program, and debug the entire program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I know this is really tempting to do, and I do it all the time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But don't do it, OK?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because you're going to introduce a lot of bugs,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and it's going to be hard to isolate which bugs are

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: affecting other ones.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it'll lead to a lot more stress than you need.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Instead, do unit testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So write one function, test the function, debug the function,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: make sure it works, write the other function, and so on,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Do a little regression testing, a little more unit testing,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a little integration testing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's a lot more systematic way to write the program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it'll cut down on your debugging time immensely.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you're changing your code, and inevitably

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you'll be changing your code as you're doing your problem sets,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: remember to back up your code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if you have a version that almost works,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: don't just modify that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Maybe save a copy.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You've got terabytes of memory on your computer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It won't hurt to just make a quick copy of it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Document, maybe what worked and what didn't in that copy.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then make another copy.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you can modify your code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's sort of a high level introduction

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to testing and debugging.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The rest of the class will be on the error messages,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or on errors that you will get in your programs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when you run functions or when you run your program,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: at some point the program execution is going to stop.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Maybe it encountered an error because

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of some unexpected condition.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And when that happens, you get an exception.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the error is called an exception.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's called an exception because it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: was an exception to what was expected,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to what the program expected.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So all of these errors that I've talked

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: about in the previous slides are actually

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: examples of exceptions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And there are actually many other types of exceptions,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which you'll see as you go on in this course

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and also in 6.0.0.2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So how do we deal with these exceptions?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In Python, you can actually have handlers for exceptions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if you know that a piece of code

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: might give you an error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For example, here I'm dealing with inputs from users.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And users are really unpredictable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You tell them to give you a number,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: they might give you their name.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Nothing you can do about that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or is there?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Yes, there is.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in your program, you can actually

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: put any lines of code that you think might be problematic,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that might give you an error or an exception,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in this try block.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you say try colon.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you put in any lines of code that you think

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: might give you an error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If none of these lines of code actually produce an error,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then great.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Python doesn't do anything else.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It treats them as just if they were part of a regular program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But if an error does come up, for example,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: if someone doesn't put in a number but puts their name in,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that's going to raise an error, specifically a value error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And at that point, Python is going to say,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is there an accept statement?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if so, this accept statement is going to handle the error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's going to say, OK, an error came up,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but I know how to handle it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to print out this message to the user.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if we look at code, this is the same code as in the slides.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And there's no try except block around it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if I run it and I say 3 and 4, it's going to run fine.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But if I run it and I say a, it's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to give a value error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Now if I run the same piece of code with a try except block,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I run it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I give it regular numbers, it's fine.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But if I'm being a cheeky user and I say 3,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: automatically this would have raised a value

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: error in the previous version of the program.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But in this version of the program,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the programmer handled the exception

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or caught the exception and printed out

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: this nicer looking message.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So bug in user input is nicer than this whole lot here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: A lot easier to read.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So any problematic lines of code,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can put in a try block and then handle whatever errors

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: might come up in this except block.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This except block is going to catch any error that comes up.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you can actually get a little bit more specific

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and catch specific types of errors.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In this case, I'm saying if a value error comes up,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for example, if the user inputs a string instead of an integer,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: do this, which is going to print this message.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If the user inputs a number for b such that we're

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: doing a divided by b, so that would give a zero division

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: error, in that case we're going to catch this other error

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: here, this zero division error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we're going to print this other message.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Can't divide by 0.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you can think of these different except blocks

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as sort of if, else, if statements,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: except for exceptions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we're going to try this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But if there's a value error, do this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Otherwise, if there's a division error, do this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And otherwise, do this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this last except is actually going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to be for any other error that comes up.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if it's not a value error nor a division error,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: something went very wrong.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I couldn't even try to make the program come up

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with any other error besides those two.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So a lot of the time, you're just

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to use try except blocks.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But there's other blocks that you can add to exceptions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these are more rarely used.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But I'll talk about them anyway.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you could have an else block.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And an else block is going to get

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: executed when the code in the try block

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: finished without raising an error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you can also have a finally block,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which is always executed if the code in the try block

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: finished without an error, if you raised an exception,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: if you raised a different kind of exception,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: if you went through the else.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In any of these cases, whatever is in the finally block

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is always going to get executed.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's usually used to clean up code,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: like if you want to print, oh, the program finished,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or if you want to close a file, or something like that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we've encountered errors.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We've caught them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What else can we do with exceptions?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Three other things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So one is if we've caught an error,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we can just fail silently.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What this means is you've caught an error,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and you just substitute whatever erroneous value

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the user gave you for some other value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's not actually a very good idea.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's a bad idea.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because suddenly, the user thinks

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that they entered something, and they think everything's great.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Your program accepts it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But then they get some weird value as an output,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which is far from what they expected.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's not really a good idea to just replace user's values

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with anything.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is in the context of a function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In the context of a function, what else can we do?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, if you have a function that fails, for example,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: let's say you're trying to get the square root of an even

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: number.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And let's say the user gives you a negative number.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, if the user gives you a negative number,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: if your function could return an error value, which means,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: well, if the input is less than 0, then return 0, or minus 1,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or minus 100.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Just pick any value to return, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: represents some error value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is actually not a good idea either,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because later on in your program,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: if you're using this function, now you have to do a check.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the check is, well, if the return from this function

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is minus 1, or minus 100, do this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Otherwise, do this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you're complicating your code,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because now you always have to have this check for this error

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: value, which makes the code really messy.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The other thing we can do is we can signal an error condition.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is how you create control flow in your programs

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with exceptions.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in Python, signaling an error condition

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: means raising your own exception.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So so far, we've just seen the programs crashing,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which means they raise an exception,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and then you deal with them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But in this last case, you're raising your own exception

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as a way to use that exception later on in the code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in Python, you raise your own exception using this raise

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: keyword, and then an exception, and then

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: some sort of description, like user entered a negative number

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or something like that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: A lot of the time, we're going to raise a value error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if the number is less than 0, then

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: raise a value error, something is wrong.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The keyword, the name of the error,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and then some sort of descriptive string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, so let's see an example of how we raise an exception.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I have this function here called get ratios.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It takes in two lists, L1 and L2,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and it's going to create a new list that's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to contain the ratio of each element in L1

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: divided by each element in L2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I have a for loop here, for index in range length L1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I'm going through every single element in L1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to try here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to try to do this line.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I think that this line might give me an error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I'm going to put it in a try block.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The error I think I'm going to get

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is a zero division error, because what

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: happens when an element in L2 is 0?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And when an element in L2 is 0, I'm

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to append this not a number as a float.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So nan as a string, you can convert it to a float,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and it stands for not a number.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So then I can continue populating the list

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with these not a numbers if an element in L2 is 0.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And otherwise, if there's no zero division error,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but there's another kind of error,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then I'm going to raise my own error

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and say, for any other kind of error,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: just raise a value error, which says get ratios was

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: called with a bad argument.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So here I'm consolidating all errors into my one value error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So later on in my program, I can catch this value error

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and do something with it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Here's another example of exceptions.

chunks.text: So let's say we're given a class list.

chunks.text: We have a list of lists where we have the name of a student,

chunks.text: is the same thing as the last one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but I'm appending an extra value at the end of the list

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for each student, which is the average of all of their grades.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's look at the code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is a function that takes the class list, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is this whole list here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm creating a new list inside it, initially empty.

chunks.text: And then I'm going for every element in the class list.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is going to be this first list here.

So write as many functions as you can. Document what the functions do. Document their constraints. And it'll make your life a little bit easier later on when you have to debug it. When do you want to start testing? Well, first you have to make sure your program runs. So eliminate syntax errors and static semantic errors, which, by the way, Python can easily catch for you. Once you've ensured that a piece of code runs, then you want to come up with some test cases. So this is pairs of input and output for what you expect the program to do. Once you have your test cases and a piece of code that runs, you can start doing tests. So there's three general classes of tests that you can do. The first is called unit testing. And if you've written functions, unit testing just makes sure that, for example, each function runs according to the specifications. So you do this multiple times. As you're testing each function, you might find a bug. At that point, you do regression testing. Come up with a test case that found that bug. And run all of the different pieces of your code again to make sure that when you fix the bug, you don't reintroduce new bugs into pieces of the code that had already run. So you do this a bunch of times. You do a little bit of unit testing, a little bit of regression testing, and keep doing that. At some point, you're ready to do integration testing, which means test your program as a whole. Does the overall program work? So this is the part where you take all of the individual pieces, put them together, and integration testing tests to make sure that the interactions between all of the different pieces works as expected. If it does, great, you're done. But if it doesn't, then you'll have to go back to unit testing and regression testing and so on. So it's really a cycle of testing. So what are some testing approaches? The first, and this is probably most common with programs that involve numbers, is figuring out some natural boundaries for the program. So for example, if I have a function is bigger, and it compares if x is bigger than y, then some natural boundary given the specification is if x is less than y, x is greater than y, x is equal to y, maybe throw in less than or equal to, or greater or equal to, and so on. So that's just sort of an intuition about the problem. It's possible you have some problems for which there are no natural partitions, in which case you might do some random testing. And then the more random testing you do, the greater the likelihood that your program is correct. But there's actually two more rigorous ways to do testing. And one is black box testing, and the other one is glass box testing. In black box testing, you're assuming you have the specifications to a function. So that's the doc string. All you're looking at is the doc string and coming up with some test cases based on that. In glass box testing, you have the code itself, and you're trying to come up with some test cases that hit upon all of the possible paths through the code. All right. Let's look at an example for black box testing. I'm finding the square root of x to some close enough value given by this epsilon. And the idea here, notice I don't actually give you how this function is implemented. The idea is that you're just figuring out test cases based on this specification. And the great thing about black box testing is that whoever implements this function can implement it in whatever way they wish. They can use approximation method. They can use bisection method. It doesn't matter. The test cases that you come up with for this function are going to be exactly the same, no matter what the implementation. So for this particular function, here's a sample set. We check the boundary. We check perfect squares. We can check some number that's less than 1. We can check maybe your rationals. And then you do extreme tests. So when either epsilon is really large or epsilon is really small or x is really large or x is really small and all the possible combinations of those. So the important thing about black box testing is that you are creating the test cases based on the specifications only. Glass box testing, you're using the code itself to guide your test cases. If you have a piece of code and you come up with a test case that goes through every single possible combination of every single possible path through the code, then that test set is called path complete. The problem with this is when you encounter loops, for example. Every single possible path through a loop is maybe the code not going through the loop at all, going through once, going through twice, going through three times, four times, five times, and so on. Which could be a very, very big test set. So instead, there are actually some guidelines for when you're dealing with loops and things like that. So for branches, when you're doing glass box testing, it's important you should just exercise all of the parts of the conditional. So make sure you have a test case that goes through each part of the conditional. For for loops, make sure you have a test case where the loop is not entered at all, whether the loop is entered one time and when the loop is entered just some number more than once. For while loops, similar to for loops, except that make sure you have test cases that cover all of the possible ways to break out of the while loop. So if the while loop condition becomes false, or if maybe there's a break inside the while loop, and so on. So in this example, we have the absolute value of x. This is a specification, and this is the implementation that someone decided to do for this function. And otherwise, which means pick a number greater than minus 1, so 2. So 2 and minus 2 are path complete, yields a path complete test suite. But notice that while we've hit upon every possible path through this code, we've actually missed a test case, minus 1. So for glass box testing, in addition to making sure you're going through all the possible paths through the code, you also want to make sure you hit upon any boundary condition.
